q1.question:
The concepts behind the functional programming paradigm require functions to be ____, meaning functions only rely on their given inputs to produce an output. A benefit of using such ____ functions is the reduction of ____, which occur when there are changes performed within a function's operation that are outside its scope.

To support this programming paradigm, Python supports ____ functions, which means you can pass functions as arguments to other functions. Three common higher-order functions in Python are:

  • ____: This function takes in a function and applies it to each item in an iterable to create a new iterable object.
  • ____: This function takes in a function and applies it to each item in an iterable to create a new iterable object that contains only elements that returned True.
  • ____: This function takes in a function and applies it to each item in an iterable to accumulate or aggregate into a single value.

To create anonymous functions that we can pass to the higher-order functions above, we can use ____ expressions.

Because the first two higher-order functions above return iterables, we can re-write them using ____, which are a more Pythonic way of making lists.

Rather than materializing or populating a whole list or iterable, we can produce items one-by-one using a ____ function that contains the yield keyword.
